content: Singaporean chef and authorThis article may **require cleanup** to meet Wikipedia's quality standards. The specific problem is: **Needs infobox, clearer sections, and updated sentencing details.** Please help improve this article if you can. *(July 2025)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **Bryan Koh** is a Singaporean chef and cookbook author, known for his writing on Southeast Asian cuisines. ## Early life and education Koh's mother was born in [Penang](/wiki/Penang), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia). He attended the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore) for a bachelor's degree in mathematics, and later [Cornell University](/wiki/Cornell_University) for a master's degree in hospitality. ## Career Bryan and his sister co-founded Chalk Farm, a cake company in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). In 2012, as [Myanmar](/wiki/Myanmar) began to open to the international community, Koh's began research research for his book, *0451 Mornings are for Mont Hin Gar*. In 2019, he published *Bekwoh, Stories & Recipes from Peninsula Malaysia's East Coast* in 2019, focusing on the cuisine of [Pahang](/wiki/Pahang), [Terengganu](/wiki/Terengganu), and [Kelantan](/wiki/Kelantan). In 2019, he published *Tamu: A Guest at the Bornean Table*. ## Publications - *Milk Pigs and Violet Gold* (2013) - *0451 Mornings are for Mont Hin Gar: Burmese Food Stories* (2015) - *Milkier Pigs & Violet Gold: Philippine Food Stories* (2016) - *Bekwoh: Stories & Recipes from Peninsula Malaysiaâ€™s East Coast* (2019) - *Tamu: A Guest at the Bornean Table* (2022) - *Mornings are for Mohinga, Regional Burmese Food* (2025) This Singaporean biographical article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Bryan Koh
